dialogues.text: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (FHLMC), commonly known as Freddie Mac, this is a public government-sponsored enterprise. Freddie Mac buys mortgages on the secondary market, pools them, and sells them as a mortgage-backed security to investors on the open market...

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (overlapping the above) I'd like to tell you that it was pressure from parents that led me to major in finance...

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC, (IN VISION)
dialogues.text: ...It wasn’t. I just hadn’t considered an alternative. What would that look like anyway? - Getting left behind - that’s what it would look like. Being one of those guys who turns up at weddings in his dad’s shirt wearing old shoes and no blazer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the class draws to a close and students file out Actor Eric stands putting his books into his bag. A group of pr looking male students pass along the row above, as Eric notices them he makes to run for it but it’s too late. As they pass him each one takes a swipe at him - the first pushes his bag and books off the desk, the next pulls Eri jacket down off his shoulders trapping is arms - the next pushes him over onto the plastic seats and the last pours end of a can of coke onto his face.

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After I quit Sigma Epsilon Phi, they put out like a ‘hit’ on me - which basically meant actives or pledges had to fight me or fuck with me any time they saw me in public. It was around this time I get a voicemail out of the blue from Warren. We weren’t speaking at the time - we’d had a falling out over some of the proceeds from the fake ID business.  55

dialogues.speaker: VOICEMAIL LADY
dialogues.text: You have one new message, first message:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (WITH BAD FRENCH ACCENT)
dialogues.text: In my own country I am in a Far-off land . I am strong but have no force or power . I win all yet remain a loser .. At break of Day I say goodnight .. When I lie down I have a Great Fear of falling.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. WARREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Warren is reading aloud from the epigraph to Hell’s Angel Hunter S Thompson - speaking the above lines down the pho He lies on his bed with The Hills on MTV in the backgroun

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: ..-Eric, it’s Warren. I need to talk to you. It’s important. Call me back please man. INT. ERIC’S CAR - NIGHT Eric is driving listening to hip hop.

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When I called him back he said he couldn’t talk about it over the phone. Said he needed to meet somewhere noisy. Eric pulls into the parking lot in front of a Pazzo’s piz parlour. He gets out and we follow him toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric sees Warren sat in a booth toward the back of the restaurant as he approaches Warren stands up and goes to him a hug. Eric goes to shake his hand instead.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Listen man I want to put all the nonsense behind us. Get back on track - it’s fucking ridiculous - seriously, we’re like brothers you and me. You have to know I never took that money.  56

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: (cold) What’s going on Warren? What did you need to talk about that you couldn’t say over the phone? I thought you might be in some sort of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: My parents are splitting up. My dad gambled all their savings away.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: Fuck, that’s harsh - I’m sorry to hear that, your Dad’s pretty much the coolest out of everyone’s I know.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Yeah well I’m not sure my mom would agree. Anyway, fuck them - that’s their business. Not what I wanted to talk about - let’s get some fucking drinks. Warren leaves Eric alone in the booth. Eric fiddles with beer mat.

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was impossible to hate Warren and I did want to...

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC
dialogues.text: .-.-I never did find out what happened with the money that went missing. I had some theories but I guess what I did know for certain is that you just don’t get too many chances in life to have a friend like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warren returns with a pitcher of beer.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Before I tell you what I’m going to tell you I need to ask you something deadly serious. I’m not fucking around.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: The only other person who knows about this is Spencer. After I tell you about this there will be no going back so if you think you might not want to know you better tell me now and we’ll never say another word about it.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: Kind of hard for me answer that without the faintest idea what you’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: What I’m going to tell you could be life- changing and I need to know if you’re in or you’re out - this is not some frat shit - it will make that shit look like child's play. It may have serious consequences.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: How am I gonna tell you if I’m in or out without you telling me the first thing about what I might be in or out of?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: I need you to say in principal. It would be something not exactly legal and we might have to leave the country very fucking fast and we might have to leave a lot of the people we love behind and so I need to know if this is something you would consider. You're either in or you're out. FREEZE PICTURE - prelap (V.0O.) cut to:

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC
dialogues.text: So this is what Warren does - he has the ability to make you feel like your life is suddenly interesting - that there might be a whole side to it that you're just completely missing out on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric thinks and Warren waits for an answer. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: Would we have to go tonight?  58

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: (finding this funny) No we wouldn't have to go tonight, are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: (relieved) OK... well, then I guess I’m in.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. SPENCER'S ACURA LEGEND
dialogues.text: Track in on the car - Warren and Spencer are in the front Eric is sat in the back - they are watching the library f afar.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Fridays are the quietest days both in terms of students and staff. Between the hours of 8am and 12pm there is a total of nine members of staff on duty - this includes: 5 librarians - three situated at the issue desk, 2 in the office, one on the reference...

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC
dialogues.text: I didn’t know what the fuck I thought I was signing up for but it sure as shit wasn’t that. I think I thought Warren was presenting me with some kind of friendship test and the only way to pass was to say yes. First I thought it was a joke then I guess I was shocked. They were deep into it - I mean deep - to the point that Warren seemed to be barely doing anything else with his life. Warren tells me about the buyers in Amsterdam, he says -

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: (speaking Eric’s words) They already think we have the books - now all we gotta do is steal ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER
dialogues.text: It wasn’t that I didn’t trust Eric it’s just that I didn’t know him as well as Warren did - we were never close. I didnt know if he could keep a secret.  59

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC
dialogues.text: Far as I could see they didn’t have even the beginning of a plan for how to actually get the artwork out - I guess that’s where I came in.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Did they ever mention a figure to you? An amount of money?

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC
dialogues.text: Warren mentioned the sum of um, twelve million dollars - that’s what they felt was what we’d get for everything. Twelve million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The top shot of the hands, the paper and the dots of pigm we can now just about begin to make out a barely identifi image made up of hundreds of tiny points of colour. INT. WARREN’S BEDROOM - DAY. The three lads are standing staring at something - their of Warren's Heist Wall, which by now has grown in size an detail. There are pictures of the exits, the parking lot, various members of staff - all connected by an elaborate series of pins, arrows and coloured string that seems dev of any obvious logic.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: It’s a bit like that scene in A Beautiful Mind - only that guy was a genius.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Yeah well it has a logic to me.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: I cannot wait to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric and Spencer are lying on their stomachs overlooking library. Eric is looking through the binoculars, behind h Warren is walking precariously around the roof ledge like tightrope walker.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Eric got sucked in same as we were. He wanted to go back to the beginning, he needed to see it all for himself - look at him, all of sudden he’s Robert fucking DeNiro in Heat.  60 Binocular POV - we see a staff member leaving, locking an punching a code into a keypad.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: Electronic keypads.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: They have Electronic keypads on the doors - that means the doors have electronic locks which will be connected to the main alarm circuit. Even if we could figure out how to kill the bell on the alarm itself, it’s probably connected into a central security hub.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: Central security hub? Spencer and Warren exchange a look. Warren climbs down, g out his notebook and starts to write.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: There'll be a safety department office for the entire campus - that’s where they'll be monitoring all the CCTV, the alarms and motion sensors and shit - Wait. (noticing Warren) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: I’m taking notes - you know, minutes.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: Are you fucking retarded? Why don’t you fax the FBI and ask where they’d like us to leave fingerprints...

dialogues.speaker: REAL WARREN
dialogues.text: I was grateful for Eric’s input - he has a real head for logistics but as I saw it this was my deal. I brought him in and I figured ultimately, I already kind of had a plan.

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC
dialogues.text: Warren is impulsive, which is something you definitely do need in a criminal gang otherwise there could be a serious lack of risk-taking which you have to have - but you need someone who’s going to look at the bigger picture and avoid any fuck- ups. Spencer? Well, Spencer was the only one of us who was a Transy student and could basically go whereever he wanted on campus - he was the inside man.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER
dialogues.text: I wasn’t interested in being the ring- leader. I guess I mainly just wanted to feel as far outside my comfort zone as humanly possible - that definitely did not mean going to jail though, yeah... that would be too far.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: (still looking through the binos) It can’t be done at night. It’s the one time when no-one is supposed to be in the building so it’ll be almost impossible to get in - we have to do it when the library's open. How many cameras did you say were in the special collections room?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: Two that I could see.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: So we need to find out who’s watching, when and for how long.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: OK good. I would concur with that. Spence you need to get inside the Safety Department Office and see who’s got eyes on the library. Eric rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: OK Jason Bourne, and how exactly do you suggest I go about finding out who’s got ‘eyes on the library’?  62

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bank of grainy security monitors. Angle on Spencer look at them transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Son...? Son? - You said you think it was stolen? From your person? A security guard sat behind a messy desk tries to regain Spencer's attention. SECURITY GUARD (CONT’D) Son? Two other security guards are sat in front of the screens absorbed in anything but monitoring them. The security gu at the desk pours coffee from a thermos flask. Spencer mo further into the room.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: Well I fell asleep in the library and when I woke up my wallet was missing.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Have you checked lost and found? Library isn’t exactly a hotbed of crime.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: Um, no. I’m pretty sure it was stolen and I thought you might have security footage from when it happened? He feels this gives him an excuse to look back in the direction of the monitors. He picks out the parking lot a the front of the library but nothing of the interior or t rear of the building.

dialogues.speaker: SECURTITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Well you'd need to file a police report and they would have to request the tapes from us - not something we can help you with directly.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: But you have cameras inside the library?

dialogues.speaker: SECURTITY GUARD
dialogues.text: We're not at liberty to discuss where the cameras are or ain’t and strictly speaking you’re not supposed to be in here either.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: OK, I’11 check with lost and found in case it got handed in.  63 Spencer backs out of the office watching the screens as h goes. His POV - pushing in - one of the screens shows a bird's eye view of the campus parking lot - virtually emp and in the bottom left corner we see a familiar car - a pedestrian approaches and opens a rear door and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spencer slides into the back seat. Warren and Eric are in front.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Well? Did you get in the room?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: Yeah - nothing of the inside so far as I could see. The only interiors I could see were of like the main building, reception, the trophy cabinet, the gym, the pool, shit like that.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: And were the screens changing - like rotating through a bunch of different cameras?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: Nope - they were all just fixed on the same thing. They can see us sat right here though. Warren starts up the engine.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: Man, how can they have millions of dollars worth of shit stashed right in there and no cameras on it?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: Yeah, someone should probably write a letter. Warren puts the car in gear and screeches out of the park lot.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Warren moved into the basement of the bungalow where Eric lived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a shot of a classic suburban Lexington bungalow complete with pruned hedge and perfect lawn. More a grann flat than a criminal HQ.  64

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (IN VISION)
dialogues.text: Eric was living with Chas at the time who he and Warren had gone to Lexington Catholic High with... We flashback to the graduation scene we saw at the top:

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Charles Allen! Modest applause as a straight-laced looking boy makes his to the podium.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Chas’ dad was a bigshot real estate guy, he owned the bungalow and Chas lived upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chas, conventionally good looking and preppy is cycling o exercise bike in the middle of the living room whilst doi weights, looking at himself in the mirror and watching Bloomberg TV on a big plasma screen.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I never cared much for Chas if I’m honest - we had zero in common. He was all about money, that was his thing. WE SINK down through the floor until we are in: INT. WARREN’S BASEMENT Warren is standing in front of what looks to be a window covered by a large set of floral curtains - he pulls a co and the curtains separate to reveal not a window but the Heist Planning Wall now in it’s new home - yet more detai and seemingly more ordered. Spencer and Eric nod approvin from the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think the planning could have gone on forever. But then something happened.

dialogues.speaker: A TELEVISION
dialogues.text: The local morning news plays - a squeaky smiley blonde fe anchor and a jock-like co-hoast with a punchable face:  65

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE NEWSREADER
dialogues.text: Good news if you woke up wondering if you were living in the right town today folks as Forbes Magazine names Lexington ‘9th best place to launch a business or career in the United States’. Bob, how about that? Do you agree? - You don’t seem to be doing too badly yourself.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Ha, that’s right Loraine. According to Forbes, the best metro areas to launch a business or a career revolve around universities that offer a diverse, educated work force. Lexington comes in just behind Huntsville, Alabama and just ahead of Richmond, Virginia.... We reveal that the TV is playing in the waiting room outs the Dean of the University of Kentucky’s office. The room empty except for Warren who stares blankly at the TV anda plump over-adorned secretary (70s) with a thirty year old hairdo sits doing sudoku until her intercom buzzes and sh picks it up:

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: No, you have a student waiting and then nothing until Mrs Palmer’s leaving lunch at Pomodoro... well Bruce generally has the Linguine and doesn’t seem to suffer too much after... I’1l send him through. She puts down the phone and addresses Warren. SECRETARY (CONT’D) You can go through... Warren is lost in the morning show. SECRETARY (CONT’D) Mr Lipka? - You can go through. Warren comes round from wherever he’s been and walks towa the dean’s office. He looks tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dean (late 50s) is a man at one with his place in the world - confident, Christian and untroubled by life’s big questions.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Take a seat Warren. Warren sits in front of the dean’s desk and takes in the walls adorned with photos depicting the glittering succes of former students. A photo of the Dean himself with Geor beams from the mantelpiece.  66

dialogues.speaker: DEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well this is unexpected wouldn’t you say?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: I guess it is sir.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Son, you came here on a soccer scholarship. Perhaps you don’t quite appreciate what that means- Warren opens his mouth to speak -

dialogues.speaker: DEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What it means is that you are one of a tiny handful of athletes who have beaten off thousands of others to be given free tuition at one of America’s top tier academic institutions. Does that not sound like something to you? Cos it sure as heck does to me.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Yes sir it does.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Well son you have an interesting way of showing it because you've just pissed it away. Coach Morris says here you have consistently failed to show up on time if at all for training, your commitment is next to non-existent. Your father aware of this?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: No sir.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: What do you imagine he’ll have to say about it?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Actually, things aren’t going so well at home at the moment sir.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: That's as maybe but it’s no excuse. A man has to be responsible for his actions Warren and those actions have consequences. Warren ‘s POV past the Dean to the faces grinning down at - so content in their shit-eating picture-perfect lives.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: (inaudibly) The sack  67

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Come again son?... Warren is elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It pains me to see you lose this scholarship and I know it’s gonna pain your pop a whole lot more. You might want to think about what that kind of disappointment will be not just for you but for your family. Warren nods thoughtfully, then speaks without anger.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Well sir. I’ve worked my ass off to get on that team since I was about five, and you know what? I have zero idea why. To be honest sir, I think you and this whole place are the real disappointment. The Dean cocks his head - fairly sure he’s misheard this.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: After that the robbery was pretty much all Warren had to think about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same top shot of the hands, the paper and the dots of pigment - hundreds of tiny points of colour - the suggest of an eye. INT. BUNGALOW - WARREN’S BASEMENT - DAY We find Warren sitting alone - the Heist Wall behind him the debris of a man with no better place to be. He sits smoking and drinking whisky from a crystal tumbler, on th is the scene from the Thomas Crown affair in which Steve McQueen is sat in a palatial Manhattan office telephoning members of his criminal gang and telling them: “Go”. He s to come to a snap decision, reaches for the TV remote, hi mute, picks up the phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Hello, could you please put me through to the library... um, yeah the main library, Special Collections Room please....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spencer plays pinball whilst Warren stands next to him.  68

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: And you know what craziest bit of it is? You can actually request them to have the books laid out for you when you arrive for an appointment - they actually get them ready for you.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: How do you know all this?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: I made an appointment.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: You did what?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: I made an appointment - I used your name and I said we wanted to view the Audubons and you wanted to bring a friend. Spencer stops what he’s doing and turns to look at Warren is more concerned about Spencer taking his eye off the pinball machine - he notices that Spencer is irritated. ACTOR WARREN (CONT’D) It’s time man. It’s time. CLOCK - the one we saw in the opening sequence - striking

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spencer's POV - We are gliding up a wide curving staircas students passing us on the way down. We are trailing a sm male librarian who turns back to address us:

dialogues.speaker: MALE LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: You're a little late so she probably won't have long. They follow him to the top of the stairs and toward the g doors of the Special Collection Museum - once there, he t on the glass to get BJ’s attention. Inside the room BJ wa toward the door and places a keycard over a small electro panel, a red light turns green on the keypad outside and male Librarian holds open the door for them. They enter a he shuts the door which locks behind them, the light turn red and he re-descends the stairs leaving the boys inside room alone with BJ. We see all of the above in detail as Warren observes, making a mental note of each part of the process.  69

dialogues.speaker: BETTY-JEAN
dialogues.text: Please sign in on your right. I have the Audubon laid out over here and the Illuminated Manuscript at the back. Was there one you wanted to view first? Warren is taking it all in - the glass cases, motion sens the low-lighting, the books, locks on each cabinet - it’s if he’s been let into Aladdin's cave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three boys are sitting around a table on which Spence has created a scale model of the Special Collections room Complete with tiny figurines to represent BJ and each of boys.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: The cameras aren’t cameras - they’re motion detectors - they are here and here and they aren’t on during the day. And back here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spencer is pouring over the Audubon Birds of America - fi edition. He seems lost in its beauty.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY-JEAN
dialogues.text: I understand you are a fine-arts major. Do the Manuscripts feature in your studies? I don’t generally get much interest in these from students. Spencer looks up - his mind elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: REAL BETTY-JEAN
dialogues.text: He seemed rather offhand. He wasn’t interested in having a conversation, didn’t seem willing to discuss his project and my impression was that he seemed rather aloof. Having said that, I did feel he was respectful of the books.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Wow, and so after the Audubon, which are the next most valuable in the collection? Bet everyone asks that, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As before, Warren is as focused as we’ve seen him - he po to the relevant locations on the model.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: And back here, my furry friends is the staff elevator. (stroking the model elevator) Ah, sweet, sweet elevator - let me inside you.. What do you fucking know? An elevator which goes directly to the basement from where we can gain access to the fire exit at the rear of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BJ is touring Warren around the museum proudly pointing o the books of greatest significance:

dialogues.speaker: BETTY-JEAN
dialogues.text: Well, the Origin of Species is one of only two first editions in the United States and then there’s The Illuminated Manuscripts which are obviously handwritten and illustrated rather than printed. So you see they are absolutely one of a kind. Priceless really.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: The books will be laid out for us here and here. We will ask for the two Audubons - the most valuable books in the collection - to be on display for us when we arrive. The other books we are going to take are in the cases here and here. They will be locked.  71

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER
dialogues.text: I just kept waiting... waiting for the thing to come along that was going to stop us. But the deeper we went, the easier it seemed to get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are inside the scale model at ground level - Warren is full flow - as he speaks we see the figurines which repre each of them manipulated by giant fingers - like a puppet show in which the figurines are the ones doing the talkin

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: BJ needs to be brought down hard and fast - she has to become a non-factor as soon as the other member of staff is out of sight. She is the single biggest risk to us. Angle on Figurine Warren. ACTOR WARREN (CONT’D) We bring her down here maybe with a tazer - we tie her and gag her and put her over here where she can’t be seen from the doorway. As Warren describes this we see short steadicam sequences which we see precisely what he envisages executed with military precision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warren (dressed in a sharp suit) is let into the room, ma Clooney-esque pleasantries - BJ turns her back on him and one deft movement Warren grabs her and tazers her, catche her neatly as she falls and then glides with her around t corner laying her down out of sight. He gags her gently w her own neckerchief, zip-ties her hands and feet like a p and lays a blanket over her.

dialogues.text: INT. WARREN’S DEN - NIGHT The scale model - we see the tiny figurine of BJ laid fac down - hands and feet tied, mouth gagged. Spencer, lookin on, slugs back a miniature bottle of bourbon, closes his eyes.  72

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: When that’s done we take her swipe card from her and let the others into the room...

Angle on the four boys who are stood in silence in Warren Den - eyes fixed on the TV. HELEN -— (CONT'D) Police say the group were highly professional and knew exactly what they were looking for...

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Highly professional - you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: Shush - Sh! Listen-  109

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: The four men made off...

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: Four? How'd they know there was four of us?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: Shush! HELEN — «+. a grey Dodge minivan. Police are appealing for anyone who believes they may have information...

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: They've got nothing! Seriously. If they had something they’d be putting out photo- fits - they don’t even know how many of us were in the van!

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: They got a pretty damn good description of it.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: With false plates. And guess what? That van'’s probably in Indiana by now. They join arms and start to dance a kind of celebratory j even Spencer who is reticent joins in - the relief - a mo of what feels like joyful friendship that might bond them together for all time. They spin around singing, screamin and laughing as Fugazi’s ‘Waiting Room’ fades in. The pic freezes and the sound echoes over: INT. ERIC’S FORD EXLORER - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: CAR STEREO
dialogues.text: A hand turns off the music. Inside the car Spencer drives Chas and Eric are stoned or asleep in the back and Warren sits reading in the passenger seat. In his hand is the st first edition of Darwin’s Origin of Species.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: (reading aloud) -.."not one of our domestic animals can be named which has not in some country drooping ears; and the view which has been suggested that the drooping is due to disuse of the muscles of the ear, from the animals being seldom much alarmed, seems probable”. Far out. D’you understand what this means dude?  110

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: (from the back - eyes still closed) It means that we have evolved to a point where we are no longer equipped to survive. We are equipped only to consume and die.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Exactly, it’s not just pets - it’s us. we're so used to being spoon fed that our muscles have withered - our brains have withered. We're alive but we’ve forgotten why.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: I know what I’m living for.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: (half asleep) to munch cock.. They laugh except for Spencer who watches the road. Angle Spencer driving.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: In my mind I think I was done with it at this point. We’d fucked up, we didn’t even have the books we promised the Dutch guys. But we did get some of them so the next thing was to get them appraised before they showed up in the system as stolen...

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (IN VISION)
dialogues.text: .-+.-This was in the plan and I guess now we had to see it through to the bitter end.

dialogues.speaker: REAL CHAS
dialogues.text: I didnt agree with it. I didn’t even want to go with them to New York but I felt like I had to because if they fucked up again, we would all pay the price.  111

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: Forget it - I’m not going in. I’m telling you this is a bad fucking idea.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Chas you’re the one who’s worked at an auctioneers - you know more about this shit than any of us.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: No way, this is a whole different ball- game. I’m just saying I’m not going in there to incriminate myself on CCTV.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Well Spencer’s the only one who knows about the books so he has to go and if you're not gonna man-up for it Chas then I'll fucking do it.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: If you go in there Warren you better have an answer for everything - I’m not kidding. You slip up and we’re all fucked. You stick to the backstory - don’t give any other personal information away, you understand? Anything that doesn’t smell right, grab the books and get the hell out of there. Are you listening?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: I handled the Danish dudes, I think I can handle some suits man. Hey, does anyone know how you tie a tie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Partly REAL CCTV - classical music, a marble-floored foye with tastefully decorated Christmas Tree, a Modigliani, a large uniformed doorman and an attractive receptionist. Spencer and Warren sit fidgeting in silence.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No disguises this time - we went in looking sophisticated, serious. Warren wears a blue suit, overcoat and cravat and Spencer wears a canary yellow sports jacket and beige 70’s dress- shirt complete with ruffle (seriously). Between them is a wheelie bag.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: (a half whisper) Just how we planned it eh brother. Here we are - just you and me. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you ever think you would be sat right here, right now... An officious and attractive young woman in a red suit, MELANIE HALLORAN, approaches them - professional and hard read.

dialogues.speaker: MS HALLORAN
dialogues.text: Mr Williams and Mr Stephens? I’m Melanie Halloran, Mr Leckey’s deputy.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: (standing up) Good to meet you Miss Halloran, I’m Jesse Stephens he’s Spencer Williams. Spencer shoots Warren a look.

dialogues.speaker: MS HALLORAN
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry, Mr Leckey has been drawn away to a public auction. But if you’re happy to proceed I can try to help and then liaise with Thomas upon his return.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: The only thing is Melanie, that the man we work for, Mr Beckman, is very particular and specifically requested that we meet with Mr Leckey - is he likely to be back today?

dialogues.speaker: MS HALLORAN
dialogues.text: I would hope so but I can’t say for sure - these things can drag on. I'd hate for you to wait and for him not arrive in time. Williams and Stephens exchange a quick look.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: (all smiles) Well I guess we should go ahead with you then. MELANIE HALLORAN INTERVIEW SETUP.

dialogues.speaker: REAL MS HALLORAN
dialogues.text: They said they worked for a wealthy collector in Boston, that they had travelled to New York specially on his behalf. They made a big thing about how reclusive Mr Beckman was. I just recall that they were very strangely dressed, very strangely. One of them hardly spoke. I asked them...  113

dialogues.speaker: MS HALLORAN
dialogues.text: ..-what else can you tell me about the provenance of the books?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Well, Mr Beckman inherited the books some years ago and now wishes to realise their value through a private sale. That’s really all the information he gave us.

dialogues.speaker: MS HALLORAN
dialogues.text: Absolutely beautiful aren’t they...

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: The heron.

dialogues.speaker: MS HALLORAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: Uh, the heron - a couple of pages in, I think she’s beautiful. Melanie eyes him as if he is an endearing weirdo. From Warren, a flicker of irritation.

dialogues.speaker: MS HALLORAN
dialogues.text: They are absolutely exquisite examples. So I will discuss all this with Mr Leckey and then we can be in touch regarding the estimate and steps toward a private sale.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Well, you see, we were kind of hoping to be able to supply Mr Beckman with an estimate today.

dialogues.speaker: MS HALLORAN
dialogues.text: I’m afraid I can’t give you that without Mr Lecke’s sign-off and he may wish to view the books personally. Is there a number we can reach you on while you’re in New York? Angle on Spencer. FREEZE PICTURE.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And here's why I’m not cut out for this.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: When you say wait for their call - you mean at the hotel?  114 INT. ERIC’S FORD EXLORER - NEW YORK STREET - DAY The boys have regrouped in the car. Eric in the driver's seat, Chas beside him and Warren and Spencer in the back.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: No, on my cell. A slow dawning on Spencer.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: (animated) On which cell?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: (realising what they’ve done) Yeah, we maybe shouldn't have given them your cell number. Chas explodes

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: Are you out of your fucking tiny minds - this isn’t a game! This is serious shit - I am not going to prison because you guys are fucking incompetent. No, this isn’t happening, you have got to be kidding me! Ring your cell phone number! - ring it now! He thrusts his cellphone at Spencer. ACTOR CHAS (CONT’D) Fucking ring it! OK, I'll ring it for you dipshit. He puts the phone on loud speaker - it goes to voicemail. SPENCER’S VOICEMAIL ‘sup this is Spence. Drop it like it's hot.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: (shouting) Does that sound like a fucking art dealer to you?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: We can change the message Chas-

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: Shut up Eric. Shut the fuck up! (threatening) You need to go in there and get whatever piece of paper that has your phone number on it back right fucking now - because I shit you not, that number is going to put us all in jail you fucking little asshole.  115

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: Just calm down man - there’s nothing...

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: (losing it) Don’t tell me to calm down - you are sending us all to jail you fucking idiots! Do you understand what I’m saying or are you too fucking stupid? Chas reaches into the footwell between his legs and start pulling clothes and toiletries violently out of his bag a then suddenly produces a gun and turns round pointing it the back - everyone screams. Freeze picture.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER
dialogues.text: The gun. Yeah, no one saw that coming.

dialogues.speaker: REAL WARREN
dialogues.text: Gun?! There was never a gun. I have no memory of Chas ever pulling a gun. I feel like I would definitely remember that.

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC
dialogues.text: All I could think was the gun was going to go off like that scene in Pulp Fiction and Warren or Spencer’s brains were going to be all over the back of my car and we would all be going to prison for hundreds of years for a totally different crime.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: (screaming) This is my life you’re fucking with. This is not a game you incompetent fucks. You need to go back in there and get that number back - I don’t give a fuck what you think you know - you have killed us - you have fucking shot us all in the head. You stupid stupid cunts. CHAS INTERVIEW SET UP.

dialogues.speaker: REAL CHAS
dialogues.text: I lost it. My frustration with them was my frustration at myself for getting involved with people who were ultimately totally incompetent. I felt like my life was slipping away from me and for them it was some kind of game.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: Why did you have a gun with you?  116

dialogues.speaker: REAL CHAS
dialogues.text: Honestly, I didn’t even stop to think it was illegal in New York - cos in Kentucky you can legally carry a gun.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER
dialogues.text: But why did you own one?

dialogues.speaker: REAL CHAS
dialogues.text: Er, protection I guess. Everyone in Kentucky has a gun. INT. ERIC’S FORD EXLORER - DUSK Silence in the car - Eric drives. Spencer reads from one the stolen books and Warren sleeps. The shine has come of Chas gazes out the window. Rain.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No one was going back to get the number - that would have aroused even more suspicion. We drove through the night in silence, not much was said on the way home. I guess everyone was just alone with their thoughts about the future and wondering what we were going do next. The plan was to sit on the books until the dust settled then find a buyer closer to home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spencer gets out of the car outside his dorm block. The o three stay in the car. The mood is sombre.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: See you guys around I guess. I’ll call by some time next week.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN AND ERIC
dialogues.text: See you man.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: Hey, no hard feelings OK Spence?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: Nah, it’s cool man. See you around. We are in the car as it starts to pull off - we watch Spe turn and walk in the direction of the dorm block until he out of sight. Teenage Wasteland by The Who fades up and continues to pl over the following series of shots.  117

CHAS’ HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - DAY Chas on his exercise bike, lifting weights whilst watchin the final scene from the Asphalt Jungle - in which the fatally wounded hero returns home to breathe his last bre in a sun-drenched meadow near where he was born - Kentuck INT. WARREN’S DEN - NIGHT Slow push in on a pile of books wrapped in a sleeping bag underneath Warren's bed.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER
dialogues.text: Everything had changed but nothing was different. We had crossed a line and now we had to try to cross back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric is sat alone at the bar. Drunk - behind him a bunch Frat boys cavort loudly - some of whom we recognise. The camera tracks across the bar to find REAL ERIC (dressed identically) sat next to actor Eric - REAL ERIC speaks to camera:

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC
dialogues.text: Nothing had changed - the only difference was it was now somehow even more intolerable.  118 The camera tracks back to ACTOR ERIC who turns around and steams violently into the middle of the group of Frat boy arms flailing wildly - soon they get the better of him an is on the floor being pummeled - he looks strangely seren

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was spending less time with the others. Eric got into a bunch of fights and then got arrested for a DUI. EXT. ERIC’S FORD EXLORER - NIGHT We are racing along beside Eric who is driving like a bat of hell with the window down - Bank Robber by the Clash blaring on the stereo - a fat lip, black eye and a weird smile on his face. We hear a police siren wail, he checks rear view mirror and puts his foot down further.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The most fucked up thing was when Eric got caught drunk driving... The camera booms up to reveal Warren clinging to the roof rack - whooping like a lunatic and banging on the roof to faster.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... Warren was hanging off the roof.

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC
dialogues.text: The thing I could never understand at the time was why they just let us off with a caution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shot of the pointillist process we have seen before - n much more fluid and practiced - the magazine, the cutting the glue, the transfer of pigment to the image which, whi we can’t clearly make out, we can see it has grown in sca and detail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Top shot as Spencer lies in bed - he sits up wide-eyed wi jolt as if emerging from a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then one night I just woke up in the middle of the night with a sudden dreadful realisation.  119

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spencer is running down the street in a robe, slippers an pajamas. He arrives at the bungalow and begins knocking o Warren’s basement window. He (and we) get a terrible frig as he spins round to find Warren standing behind him with baseball bat.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing - you scared the shit out of me.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: The e-mails. We’re fucked. We used the same e-mail address.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR SPENCER
dialogues.text: Walter Beckman. We used the same e-mail address to e-mail the library as we used to e-mail Christies. They’1ll find Halloran and they’1l find the phone number. Chas was right - we’re fucked. We see the truth of this settle upon Warren.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And that’s when the paranoia set in. Although don’t they say it’s not paranoia if someone’s really out to get you.

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC
dialogues.text: I found it unbearable to tell you the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eric is putting a piece of scotch tape across the door ja like Redford in The Sting. INT. REAL CHAS INTERVIEW SET UP.

dialogues.speaker: REAL CHAS
dialogues.text: To me it was when and not if. I wasn’t planning to stick around for the shit to hit the fan so I made plans to take a semester off and tried to figure out how I could leave town for a while.  120 INT. CHAS’ BEDROOM - NIGHT Chas is sat at his desk with a gun in his lap - turning t desk lamp on and then off - he sits in darkness looking o at the street. A car slows down as it passes the house, h crouches down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the lecturer talks, an agitated Spencer is watching a student across the room.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A new student started on my course. He also moved into the fourth floor dorms. I was convinced he was an undercover cop. The student in question becomes aware of Spencer staring returns a half-smile and an acknowledging nod. Spencer st back grimly.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER
dialogues.text: The crazy thing was, I was right about the undercover cop - I was just wrong about who it was. From the reverse on Spencer we pull focus to an older-loo female student a couple of desks behind - her eyes fixed Spencer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warren is leaving the house - he becomes aware of a garde on the opposite side of the street, a bin man, a man ina passing car - all of whom, in his mind, seem to be watchi him. He breaks into a run.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER
dialogues.text: Hard to describe that feeling. When you know you’re on borrowed time, things are suddenly put in perspective....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spencer sits at the dinner table surrounded by his family they are laughing and eating and chinking glasses - somet being celebrated, Spencer is tipsy and seemingly overcome with love for his family.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .-.-Things seem better than you ever remember them being... because maybe you know it’s all about to disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner’s over, Spencer is leaving.

dialogues.text: Sure you're alright to drive Spence? You had a couple.

dialogues.text: Nah, I got a big day tomorrow. I love you guys - I'll see you soon. He gives his dad an overly long hug and walks out the doo

dialogues.text: Warren pushes his shopping trolley down an empty aisle of supermarket then shoves it and watches it drift away on i own - he turns and walks past the cashiers toward the exi clutching the stolen ready meal under his coat. As he nea the exit he hears:

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Excuse me sir. Sir. Stop - stop right there. INT. SPENCER’S ACURA LEGEND - NIGHT Spencer, eyes closed and speeding into the snowy night - hear the revving of the engine - finally his eyes snap op but too late - he smashes violently into the back of a ca waiting at traffic lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warren begins to run. He turns to throw the ready meal at pursuing security guard who bats it away and tackles him as he gets outside the automatic doors of the store. Warr pinned to the snowy ground looks into camera. INT. CHAS’ BEDROOM - NIGHT Eric bursts in on Chas who startles and reaches for the g that he has on the desk, fumbles it and sends it flying across the desk and out of the open window.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: Warren’s been arrested and I can’t reach Spencer. We need to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: Fuck. Fuck. Where are we going to go?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: Canada, we should go to Canada. I have a cousin there. Chas is already up and throwing clothes into a rucksack.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: You serious? I was thinking more along the lines of a motel.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: We could get on a bus tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: Go pack your shit then.  123

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: (suddenly hearing something) Sh! What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR CHAS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR ERIC
dialogues.text: (a terse whisper) There’s someone in the house. They tiptoe out of the room and edge slowly down the stai where they can clearly hear that there’s someone downstai Chas picks up a dumbbell and puts on an American football helmet and Eric grabs a walking stick as they go tentativ from room to room in relative darkness. As reach the bottom of the stairs they can see the place has been ransacked - or has it? - they turn the corner and co face to face with Warren - they all jump out of their ski

dialogues.text: Fuck, you scared the shit out of me.

dialogues.text: I heard you'd been arrested.

dialogues.text: Yeah, it was a misunderstanding - they let me go.

dialogues.text: What do you mean? What did they arrest you for Warren? CHAS INTERVIEW SET UP.

dialogues.text: Something wasn’t right. Besides Warren being a fucking idiot. You don’t bust someone for shoplifting then just let them walk free - that didn’t sit right. dialogues.text: “Tell them it’s fear of the sack. Tell them this man is fleeing St Louis because he suspects the sack is coming down on him and it’s full of something ugly...  124 INT. SPENCER'S DORMROOM - NIGHT. Spencer lies in bed staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..-and he doesn’t want to be put in with it. He senses it from afar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...this man is not a model youth. He grew up with two toilets and a football... INT. ERIC’S BEDROOM - NIGHT. Eric is propped up in bed attempting to stay awake but sl dropping off.

dialogues.speaker: ACTOR WARREN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .--but somewhere along the line he got warped. Now all he wants is Out, Flee...

dialogues.text: .---and he doesn’t give a good shit for St. Louis or his friends or his family or anything else... INT. CHAS’ BEDROOM - NIGHT Chas lies asleep with a gun in his hand resting on his ch

dialogues.text: .--he just wants to find some place where he can breathe... INT. WARREN’S DEN - NIGHT Warren is dropping off - his eyes closing slowly...

dialogues.text: (drowsily) some place where he can breathe... Is that good enough for you?” Warren falls asleep and as his arm drops to his side and book falls to the floor - we JUMP OUT OF OUR SKIN at the sound of an almighty crash as we smash cut to:  125

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The splintering of wood as the front door bursts open followed by torchlight and shouting raking the interior o the house as the FBI flood through doors and windows. The action slows to slo-mo and slower still - sync-sound drops away as Offenbach’s Barcarolle (or the like) swells we see the boys awaken rudely to the reality of what’s happening around them. Eric attempts to climb out his win onto the roof where he is met with spotlights and threats lie down with his hands on his head, Chas reaches for his and finds himself at the top of the stairs facing a screa FBI agent pointing a shotgun at him. Another housemate an his girlfriend awake naked, terrified and bewildered. At Transy campus Spencer's dorm is raided - he sits up in be with a look of mild relief on his face. Warren awakes in basement where beams of white torch light pierce the floorboards. He sits up in bed and listens to the mayhem above - then lies back down. We are high and wide pushing on Warren as he stares calmly up at us until he is finall found - lit up by torchlight and then dragged roughly fro frame. BLACK. We see REAL NEWS ARCHIVE from the arrest.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What is fear? Fear is an emotion designed to protect you from harm. It makes you avoid danger, prevents you making a silly mistake and getting eaten by a bear or some shit.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER
dialogues.text: But like Darwin said - it’s an emotion most of us don’t run into a whole lot - not real fear anyway. The kind a caveman might have had to deal with. So we look for new ways to experience something like it... As per the opening - we are driving through suburban Lexington everything green, genteel and placid. dialogues.text: INT. SPENCER'S PARENTS’ HOME —- INTERVIEW SETUP Spencer's real parents are sat together on the sofa - holding hands - as per the beginnng.

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER'S DAD
dialogues.text: What we went through I can best describe as grief. I don’t think the sentencing was fair at all. They were children. Girls mature faster. Boys are still children at that age. What more proof do you need than this?

dialogues.speaker: REAL ERIC
dialogues.text: You'll probably consider this bullshit - it doesn’t matter to me either way. But jail was the best thing that could have happened to me - not cos I needed to be punished, although I did, but because whatever was expected of me on the outside, I was free of all of it in there. Materialism, vanity, ego, all that - there’s no place for it there. I was set free. Quite the paradox huh?

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER
dialogues.text: Aprendi hablar Espanol... (Spencer delivers some of the following speech in Spanish) I shared a cell with a black guy. I met people I would never have met in my life and they taught me more than college ever would have. I felt true fear. I laughed a lot and I cried a lot. I had a seven year sabbatical from the world. It was like a second childhood almost.

dialogues.speaker: REAL WARREN
dialogues.text: We were the one percent. One percent white in a black and Latino jail. One percent rich and one percent educated. But in there it didn’t count for shit. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: REAL WARREN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I feel like it’s not until you lose everything that maybe you begin to find something. I opened a portal and I walked through it.

dialogues.speaker: REAL BJ
dialogues.text: You can dress it up however you want. The idea that this was about something other than a group of ruthless, reckless, selfish vandals trying to make a fast buck is just garbage. These people are the lowest of the low - they didn’t even steal out of necessity. They’re animals and they represent all that is wrong with our society. Cut to black.

dialogues.text: I’ve been out of prison for a year and I’m not sure what the future holds. We see present day footage of Real Chas working as a pers trainer in an upmarket health club in Santa Monica...

dialogues.speaker: REAL SPENCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But what I do know is that good or bad, it’s ours, mine - and no one else's... We see present day footage of Warren - sitting in a lectu theatre - back at University of some sort.

dialogues.text: ...We stole it... We see present day doc footage of Real Spencer at what appears to be an exhibition of his artwork.
